verbatim.problem_statement: Every child in the family needs a private place, generally centered around the bed. But in many cultures, perhaps all cultures, young children feel isolated if they sleep alone, if their sleeping area is too private.
verbatim.solution_statement: [Solution statement not available — page blocked by content filter]

forces.name: privacy vs. companionship
forces.pole_a: each child needs a private, individual place centered around their own bed
forces.pole_b: young children feel isolated and anxious if their sleeping area is too private or separate
forces.description: central tension between a child's need for personal territory and their need for proximity to siblings during sleep
forces.resolved_by: cluster of small private alcoves grouped around a shared common playspace

forces.name: shared space vs. individual territory
forces.pole_a: shared bedroom allows companionship and easy supervision but creates conflict over possessions, light, and activity
forces.pole_b: fully isolated private rooms eliminate conflict but produce loneliness and psychological isolation
forces.description: tension between the one-room shared bedroom and fully separate private rooms as competing extremes
forces.resolved_by: intermediate cluster of alcoves — small enough to be personal, grouped around a common area

forces.name: individual ownership vs. communal play
forces.pole_a: children are jealous of their toys and possessions and need a defensible personal space
forces.pole_b: children also need shared space for play and social interaction with siblings
forces.description: the need for a private retreat from siblings conflicts with the need for accessible shared play areas
forces.resolved_by: individual sleeping alcoves opening onto a central shared playspace

forces.name: enclosure vs. openness
forces.pole_a: the sleeping alcove must feel enclosed and sheltered to provide security and identity for the child
forces.pole_b: the sleeping area must not be so enclosed that the child feels cut off from the family group
forces.description: spatial tension between the cocoon-like quality of a proper sleeping nook and sufficient openness to remain connected
forces.resolved_by: alcove form — partially enclosed but opening toward the common playspace

typed_rules.preferred_value: cluster of individual alcoves around a common playspace — not one shared room, not isolated private rooms
typed_rules.rationale: Both extremes (shared room and fully private rooms) are described as bad; the cluster of alcoves resolves competing forces
typed_rules.source_text: We shall try to show that both extremes are bad; and that some version of the cluster of alcoves is needed to solve the conflict between forces in a young child's life.

typed_rules.preferred_value: small and private enough to feel personal, but not enclosed as a full room
typed_rules.rationale: Full room isolation produces feelings of loneliness in young children; the alcove is the appropriate intermediate scale
typed_rules.source_text: young children feel isolated if they sleep alone, if their sleeping area is too private

typed_rules.metric: Relationship of alcoves to common area
typed_rules.preferred_value: individual alcoves must be clustered around and open onto a shared central playspace
typed_rules.rationale: The spatial connection between private alcove and shared space is the defining move that resolves the privacy/companionship tension
typed_rules.source_text: a kind of configuration in which children have their own, small, private spaces, not as large as rooms, clustered around a common playspace

typed_rules.preferred_value: light on two sides of the cluster space
typed_rules.rationale: Cross-lighting prevents the cluster feeling dark or oppressive; referenced explicitly in concluding instructions
typed_rules.source_text: Give the entire space LIGHT ON TWO SIDES (159).

typed_rules.preferred_value: communal sleeping pattern (186) as alternative for adults
typed_rules.rationale: The bed cluster pattern is primarily for children; a distinct pattern applies when occupants are adults
typed_rules.source_text: Another version of this pattern, more suitable for adults, is given by COMMUNAL SLEEPING (186).

adjacency_rules.note: Sleeping areas for adults have been defined within the Couple's Realm; this pattern operates within that context
Sleeping areas for children are defined within Children's Realm; the bed cluster's common playspace should be shaped per that pattern
Bed cluster must be placed facing east to receive morning light, as established by this parent pattern
Adult version of the same clustering principle; referenced as the appropriate alternative when occupants are adults rather than children
Individual alcoves within the cluster must be built according to Bed Alcove specifications

adjacency_rules.target_pattern_name: Light on Two Sides of Every Room
adjacency_rules.note: The entire bed cluster space should receive light on two sides
Location of dressing areas used to help shape the bed cluster and individual alcoves
Closet placement helps shape the bed cluster and individual alcoves
Tiny nooks and crannies should be included within or near the bed cluster
Detailed shape and construction of the bed cluster space to follow this pattern

failure_modes.description: When all children share one undivided bedroom, they fight constantly over possessions, light, radio, and activities, with no defensible personal territory for any child.
failure_modes.symptom: Chronic sibling conflict, inability for any child to have quiet or personal space, mutual interference with sleep and play
failure_modes.source_text: Children are jealous of one another's toys; they fight over the light, the radio, the game being played, the door open or closed.

failure_modes.description: When each child has a fully separate private room, young children feel isolated, psychologically cut off, and lonely during sleeping hours.
failure_modes.symptom: Children feel abandoned or anxious at night; sleeping area is experienced as isolating rather than sheltering
failure_modes.source_text: young children feel isolated if they sleep alone, if their sleeping area is too private

failure_modes.description: When the sleeping alcoves are not connected to a shared playspace, children lose both the private retreat and the communal connection that the cluster pattern is designed to provide simultaneously.
failure_modes.violated_rule: Relationship of alcoves to common area
failure_modes.symptom: The arrangement reverts to either shared-room or isolated-room failure modes; neither privacy nor companionship is well served
failure_modes.source_text: a kind of configuration in which children have their own, small, private spaces, not as large as rooms, clustered around a common playspace
